awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Early-life adversity: Maternal effects in a wild primate
awd_abstract_narration:
In early life, organisms receive cues about their environment from their mother, specifically her hormones. But how offspring respond to these signals is not fully understood. This doctoral dissertation project will examine how the early-life environment and maternal “stress” hormones impact development in a long-lived, wild primate. In humans, high maternal stress can result in low offspring birth weight, which in turn predicts poor physiological status later in life. By studying a wild primate, this research will help identify why these connections exist and could inform interventions designed to help prevent negative outcomes. Additionally, this project will contribute to conservation and education at the research site and surrounding areas, through frequent presentations to local community members, tourists, and park management officials. The co-PI will also continue to mentor undergraduate women in the laboratory throughout her dissertation.

When faced with adversity, mammalian mothers have fewer resources to invest in their offspring. These mothers also experience higher levels of “stress” hormones. These hormones, through the placenta and breastmilk, can reach the offspring and indicate the mother’s divestment, potentially leading to adjusted offspring development in response to these signals. There are two possible adjustments that can occur in offspring: 1) a delay in all aspects of development, or 2) trade-offs in development, for example favoring growth over investment in the immune system. Using non-invasive fecal hormone samples, this project will first identify the social and ecological factors of the environment that result in higher maternal stress hormones. Next, using behavioral observations, the researchers will examine if maternal stress levels impact maternal behavior towards their offspring. Lastly, the researchers will non-invasively assess four aspects of offspring development (growth rate, motor skill acquisition, time to independence, and immune function) to determine if offspring respond to maternal stress hormones by delaying all developmental markers or by making trade-offs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When facing a stressor, such as a predator attack, the body produces steroid hormones called glucocorticoids which help an individual survive the stressor by regulating their metabolism. Glucocorticoids (GCs) divert energy away from non-essential functions such as digestion and provide more energy to the muscles that can be used to fight or flee from the predator. The production of GCs should therefore promote survival; however, high levels of GCs are commonly associated with reduced health and fitness in humans and other primates. 

This research aimed to investigate this discrepancy by examining how glucocorticoids may promote fitness in wild female primates when they face energetic challenges. First, we identified potential energetic challenges associated with delayed female reproductive pace and offspring development in a population of wild geladas (Theropithecus gelada) living in the Simien Mountains National Park, Ethiopia. We next investigated if female geladas facing these same challenges exhibited elevated GCs during reproduction. Then we took advantage of a natural experiment on wild white-faced capuchins (Cebus imitator) living in northwestern Costa Rica to test the relationship between glucocorticoids and survival of an extreme drought. All of this research utilized long-term demographic and behavioral data collected from habituated primate populations along with non-invasive fecal sample collection for hormonal analysis.

We identified several factors that may serve as energetic challenges for female geladas and found evidence that females may increase GCs to successfully reproduce despite these challenges. Gelada females who were of low social rank, had male infants, or were primiparous (first-time moms) exhibited longer interbirth intervals. Low-ranking and primiparous females also weaned their infants at older ages, suggesting slower infant development, and exhibited higher levels of GCs during pregnancy. Across many mammalian species, including humans, high GCs during pregnancy are associated with changes in offspring development. Future research in geladas will examine whether GCs serve as a mechanism linking the energetic challenges that mothers experience with the delayed development of their infants or other outcomes in later life. 

Our research on capuchins showed that higher GCs during periods of low rainfall predict greater survival of future energetic challenges. Using fecal samples collected across 5 years, we compared the GC levels between individuals who survived and those who died during the following two years when there was an unprecedented drought. We found that individuals with higher GCs during low rainfall had a greater likelihood of surviving. These results suggest that high GCs are not always associated with reduced fitness and can instead promote survival in the face of energetic challenges. 

Together, the results of this research advances our understanding of the role that GCs play in reproduction and survival of wild female primates. In particular, this research sets the stage for future investigations on how maternal GCs may impact offspring development, an area of interest for public health in humans. Additionally, this research fills a gap in the literature by conducting a true test of the relationship between GCs and survival in a wild primate population and provides evidence for the adaptive nature of the GC response.
